newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast spot power firm on ongoing outages.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast spot power firm on ongoing outages.

text.p: Physical prices of wholesale electricity in the southeastern U.S. remained firmed Thursday amid the ongoing outages of several key nuclear power stations in the region, market sources said.
Southeast's reduced capacity to produce electricity has been offset by temperate autumn weather in most of the region, traders said.

Duke Power Co's 846 megawatt (MW) Oconee 2 nuclear unit in Seneca, S.C. and Florida Power Corp's 825 MW Crystal River 3 unit in Red Level, Fla., remained shut, with no restart date set by either plant's operator.
Florida Power & Light Co's Turkey Point 3 nuclear unit in Florida City, Fla., was expected to return to operation by Friday after being shut Tuesday when two control rods fell into its reactor core.

In the Southeast Reliability Council (SERC), non-firm power for heavy demand hours on Friday for delivery into the northern portion of Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) system was bid near $17.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), flat from Wednesday's level.
"The momentum is up, but you can still get it $17.00," said one East Coast trader.
Friday's peak electricity in southern TVA was valued near $20.00-$21.00, compared with Wednesday's quote of $20.00 for Thursday electricity.
TVA was heard offering peak non-firm power for Friday at $17.50 per MWh and for next week $18.50. The country's largest utility was reportedly selling next-day electricity for $18.00 on Wednesday.
At the Georgia/Florida border, peak, non-firm power was quoted at $21.00-$22.00 per MWh for Friday, wider than Wednesday's $21.00-$21.50 range.
